channel.title: JBoss Issue Tracker
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [ENTESB-4429] Datasource service dependency not respected in fabric
item.description:
A basic Hibernate JPA example containing 4 bundles:
1) Datasource - datasource in blueprint - exports as a service
2) Datamodel - entity classes and persistence.xml
3) Feature - feature.xml file
4) JAX RS Webservice - Web service + persistence layer - blueprint bean jpa:context for entity manager

In Fabric, the deployment agent can not correctly correlate and manage the relationship between the exported service reference to the datasource and the lookup of that service in the persistence.xml, even when they are in separate bundles. This results in the deployment order falling back to using a sorted list. In this case, if your datasource bundle is alphabetically after the persistence.xml bundle, it leads to the bundle referencing the persistence unit to go into an unrecoverable GracePeriod and the persistence unit never being created.

If you only delete the persistence unit bundle from the cache directory between the stop and start, then starting up the container works correctly (when you use the reference).

This leads me to believe something is being cached or not shutdown correctly in the stop / start scenario.

2015-11-12 18:47:06,613 | WARN  | agent-1-thread-1 | container                        | impl.EntityManagerFactoryManager  366 | 1224 - org.apache.aries.jpa.container - 1.0.1.redhat-611452 | Error creating EntityManagerFactory
 
java.lang.RuntimeException: The DataSource osgi:service/jdbc/Hibernate_XADS required by bundle datamodel/1.0.0.SNAPSHOT could not be found.
 
	at org.apache.aries.jpa.container.unit.impl.JndiDataSource.getDs(JndiDataSource.java:86)[1224:org.apache.aries.jpa.container:1.0.1.redhat-611452]
 
	at org.apache.aries.jpa.container.unit.impl.DelayedLookupDataSource.getConnection(DelayedLookupDataSource.java:38)[1224:org.apache.aries.jpa.container:1.0.1.redhat-611452]
 
	at org.hibernate.ejb.connection.InjectedDataSourceConnectionProvider.getConnection(InjectedDataSourceConnectionProvider.java:70)[1262:org.hibernate.entitymanager:4.2.9.Final]
 
	at org.hibernate.engine.jdbc.internal.JdbcServicesImpl$ConnectionProviderJdbcConnectionAccess.obtainConnection(JdbcServicesImpl.java:242)[1261:org.hibernate.core:4.2.9.Final]
 
	at org.hibernate.engine.jdbc.internal.JdbcServicesImpl.configure(JdbcServicesImpl.java:117)[1261:org.hibernate.core:4.2.9.Final]
 
	at org.hibernate.service.internal.StandardServiceRegistryImpl.configureService(StandardServiceRegistryImpl.java:76)[1261:org.hibernate.core:4.2.9.Final]
 
	at org.hibernate.service.internal.AbstractServiceRegistryImpl.initializeService(AbstractServiceRegistryImpl.java:158)[1261:org.hibernate.core:4.2.9.Final]
 
	at org.hibernate.service.internal.AbstractServiceRegistryImpl.getService(AbstractServiceRegistryImpl.java:130)[1261:org.hibernate.core:4.2.9.Final]
 
	at org.hibernate.cfg.Configuration.buildTypeRegistrations(Configuration.java:1825)[1261:org.hibernate.core:4.2.9.Final]
 
	at org.hibernate.cfg.Configuration.buildSessionFactory(Configuration.java:1783)[1261:org.hibernate.core:4.2.9.Final]
 
	at org.hibernate.ejb.EntityManagerFactoryImpl.<init>(EntityManagerFactoryImpl.java:96)[1262:org.hibernate.entitymanager:4.2.9.Final]
 
	at org.hibernate.ejb.Ejb3Configuration.buildEntityManagerFactory(Ejb3Configuration.java:914)[1262:org.hibernate.entitymanager:4.2.9.Final]
 
	at org.hibernate.osgi.OsgiPersistenceProvider.createContainerEntityManagerFactory(OsgiPersistenceProvider.java:99)[1263:org.hibernate.osgi:4.2.9.Final]
 
	at org.apache.aries.jpa.container.impl.EntityManagerFactoryManager.createEntityManagerFactories(EntityManagerFactoryManager.java:362)[1224:org.apache.aries.jpa.container:1.0.1.redhat-611452]
 
	at org.apache.aries.jpa.container.impl.EntityManagerFactoryManager.registerEntityManagerFactories(EntityManagerFactoryManager.java:274)[1224:org.apache.aries.jpa.container:1.0.1.redhat-611452]
 
	at org.apache.aries.jpa.container.impl.EntityManagerFactoryManager.bundleStateChange(EntityManagerFactoryManager.java:216)[1224:org.apache.aries.jpa.container:1.0.1.redhat-611452]
 
	at org.apache.aries.jpa.container.impl.PersistenceBundleManager.modifiedBundle(PersistenceBundleManager.java:296)[1224:org.apache.aries.jpa.container:1.0.1.redhat-611452]
 
	at org.apache.aries.util.tracker.hook.BundleHookBundleTracker$Tracked.customizerModified(BundleHookBundleTracker.java:500)[10:org.apache.aries.util:1.0.1.redhat-611423]
 
	at org.apache.aries.util.tracker.hook.BundleHookBundleTracker$Tracked.customizerModified(BundleHookBundleTracker.java:433)[10:org.apache.aries.util:1.0.1.redhat-611423]
 
	at org.apache.aries.util.tracker.hook.BundleHookBundleTracker$AbstractTracked.track(BundleHookBundleTracker.java:725)[10:org.apache.aries.util:1.0.1.redhat-611423]
 
	at org.apache.aries.util.tracker.hook.BundleHookBundleTracker$Tracked.bundleChanged(BundleHookBundleTracker.java:463)[10:org.apache.aries.util:1.0.1.redhat-611423]
 
	at org.apache.aries.util.tracker.hook.BundleHookBundleTracker$BundleEventHook.event(BundleHookBundleTracker.java:422)[10:org.apache.aries.util:1.0.1.redhat-611423]
 
	at org.apache.felix.framework.util.SecureAction.invokeBundleEventHook(SecureAction.java:1103)[org.apache.felix.framework-4.0.3.redhat-610379.jar:]
 
	at org.apache.felix.framework.util.EventDispatcher.createWhitelistFromHooks(EventDispatcher.java:696)[org.apache.felix.framework-4.0.3.redhat-610379.jar:]
 
	at org.apache.felix.framework.util.EventDispatcher.fireBundleEvent(EventDispatcher.java:484)[org.apache.felix.framework-4.0.3.redhat-610379.jar:]
 
	at org.apache.felix.framework.Felix.fireBundleEvent(Felix.java:4650)[org.apache.felix.framework-4.0.3.redhat-610379.jar:]
 
	at org.apache.felix.framework.Felix$4.run(Felix.java:2123)[org.apache.felix.framework-4.0.3.redhat-610379.jar:]
 
	at org.apache.felix.framework.Felix.runInContext(Felix.java:2147)[org.apache.felix.framework-4.0.3.redhat-610379.jar:]
 
	at org.apache.felix.framework.Felix.startBundle(Felix.java:2121)[org.apache.felix.framework-4.0.3.redhat-610379.jar:]
 
	at org.apache.felix.framework.BundleImpl.start(BundleImpl.java:955)[org.apache.felix.framework-4.0.3.redhat-610379.jar:]
 
	at org.apache.felix.framework.BundleImpl.start(BundleImpl.java:942)[org.apache.felix.framework-4.0.3.redhat-610379.jar:]
 
	at io.fabric8.agent.DeploymentAgent.install(DeploymentAgent.java:955)[58:io.fabric8.fabric-agent:1.0.0.redhat-424]
 
	at io.fabric8.agent.DeploymentAgent.doUpdate(DeploymentAgent.java:572)[58:io.fabric8.fabric-agent:1.0.0.redhat-424]
 
	at io.fabric8.agent.DeploymentAgent$2.run(DeploymentAgent.java:293)[58:io.fabric8.fabric-agent:1.0.0.redhat-424]
 
	at java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Executors.java:471)[:1.7.0_60]
 
	at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:262)[:1.7.0_60]
 
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1145)[:1.7.0_60]
 
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:615)[:1.7.0_60]
 
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)[:1.7.0_60]
 
Caused by: javax.naming.NameNotFoundException: osgi:service/jdbc/Hibernate_XADS
 
	at org.apache.aries.jndi.url.ServiceRegistryContext.lookup(ServiceRegistryContext.java:113)[1220:org.apache.aries.jndi.url:1.0.0]
 
	at org.apache.aries.jndi.url.ServiceRegistryContext.lookup(ServiceRegistryContext.java:144)[1220:org.apache.aries.jndi.url:1.0.0]
 
	at org.apache.aries.jndi.DelegateContext.lookup(DelegateContext.java:161)[1217:org.apache.aries.jndi.core:1.0.0]
 
	at javax.naming.InitialContext.lookup(InitialContext.java:411)[:1.7.0_60]
 
	at org.apache.aries.jpa.container.unit.impl.JndiDataSource.getDs(JndiDataSource.java:65)[1224:org.apache.aries.jpa.container:1.0.1.redhat-611452]
 
	... 38 more

Even with a mandatory relationship through a reference (which isn't required for this use case), the bundle only appears to correct wait on deployment to a running container. It does not appear to enforce the bundles to correctly wait when stopping and restarting. The datamodel and datasource bundles end up in active+created states, but the entitymanagerfactory is actually never created by the bundle. The persistence layer ends up in GracePeriod due to the entity manager factory.

	<reference id="dataSource"
 
                interface="javax.sql.DataSource"
 
                filter="(datasource.name=NonXA_DS)" availability="mandatory"/>

I see 2 parts to the problem:

1) The dependencies are not being 100% respected in fabric (standalone mode can control them with bundle start levels)
2) If the persistence.xml bundle transitions to ACTIVE state, the creation of the persistence unit is never attempted even if the dependency becomes available. Aries only tries twice to create the PU, at bundle resolved and bundle active.

While things are in GracePeriod and the datasource is created, a restart of the persistence unit bundle resolves all of the issues and the service starts working.

A hackish approach using a BundleActivator to force start the datasource bundle also appears to work for the use cases I tested.
item.summary: Datasource service dependency not respected in fabric

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Hello Matthew Robson, before I check it, please consult the reference project: https://github.com/FuseByExample/esb-transactions/tree/jboss-fuse-6.2.1.

Grzegorz Grzybek I did review the reference project. The reason I believe the reference project works is due to the alphabetical sort in the fabric deployment agent. Because the datasource, datamodel and route in the reference project are alphabetically in order, each dependency is deployed correctly. This alone would probably cover quite a few cases out there. There may be some differences in 6.2.x as well.

You can see the ordering from the github page:

JBossFuse:karaf@root> osgi:list | grep -i transactions
 
[ 295] [Active     ] [Created     ] [       ] [   80] JBoss Fuse :: Examples :: Transactions :: Datasource (6.2.1)
 
[ 296] [Active     ] [            ] [       ] [   80] JBoss Fuse :: Examples :: Transactions :: Database (6.2.1)
 
[ 297] [Active     ] [Created     ] [       ] [   80] JBoss Fuse :: Examples :: Transactions :: Routing (6.2.1)

Where as in the examples where it does not work, the frontend bundle is before the datamodel and datasource. Creating the explicit import / export service allows for the the datasource and datamodel to be created, but in the stop / start scenario, the datamodel does not actually end up creating the entitymanagerfactory so the front end ends up stuck in GracePeriod.

[1538] [Active     ] [GracePeriod ] [   60] hibernatetx :: CXF Hibernate (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[1539] [Active     ] [Created     ] [   60] hibernatetx :: Datamodel (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[1540] [Active     ] [Created     ] [   60] hibernatetx :: XA-Datasource (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)


Fabric8:admin@fuse-services2> osgi:ls 1468
 
 
 
hibernatetx :: Datamodel (1468) provides:
 
------------------------------------------
 
objectClass = org.osgi.service.blueprint.container.BlueprintContainer
 
osgi.blueprint.container.symbolicname = datamodel
 
osgi.blueprint.container.version = 1.0.0.SNAPSHOT
 
service.id = 375

In my example, the datasource alphabetically comes after my datamodel and frontend and because there is no direct dependency relationship created, it fails.

As an example, I changed my datasource bundle from "org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx.xa-datasource" to "org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx.a-datasource" so it would be first, and everything starts working fine on restarts.

This looks like:

[1605] [Active     ] [Created     ] [   60] hibernatetx :: XA-Datasource (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[1606] [Active     ] [Created     ] [   60] hibernatetx :: CXF Hibernate (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[1607] [Active     ] [Created     ] [   60] hibernatetx :: Datamodel (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)

With the correct entitymanagerfactory:

Fabric8:admin@fuse-services2> osgi:ls 1607
 
 
 
hibernatetx :: Datamodel (1607) provides:
 
-----------------------------------------
 
objectClass = javax.persistence.EntityManagerFactory
 
org.apache.aries.jpa.container.managed = true
 
org.apache.aries.jpa.default.unit.name = false
 
osgi.unit.name = cxfhibernate
 
osgi.unit.provider = org.hibernate.ejb.HibernatePersistence
 
osgi.unit.version = 1.0.0.SNAPSHOT
 
service.id = 375
 
----
 
objectClass = javax.persistence.EntityManagerFactory, org.apache.aries.jpa.container.sync.Synchronization
 
org.apache.aries.jpa.container.managed = true
 
org.apache.aries.jpa.default.unit.name = false
 
org.apache.aries.jpa.proxy.factory = true
 
osgi.unit.name = cxfhibernate
 
osgi.unit.provider = org.hibernate.ejb.HibernatePersistence
 
osgi.unit.version = 1.0.0.SNAPSHOT
 
service.id = 376
 
----
 
objectClass = org.osgi.service.blueprint.container.BlueprintContainer
 
osgi.blueprint.container.symbolicname = datamodel
 
osgi.blueprint.container.version = 1.0.0.SNAPSHOT
 
service.id = 378

Matthew Robson, hmm, I have this (6.1.1.redhat-444):

[ 311] [Active     ] [Created     ] [       ] [   60] hibernatetx :: CXF Hibernate (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[ 312] [Active     ] [Created     ] [       ] [   60] hibernatetx :: Datamodel (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[ 313] [Active     ] [Created     ] [       ] [   60] hibernatetx :: XA-Datasource (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)

so the same order as you, but everything is resolved.

Before restart I have this:

JBossFuse:karaf@root> ls 362
 
 
 
hibernatetx :: Datamodel (362) provides:
 
----------------------------------------
 
objectClass = org.osgi.service.blueprint.container.BlueprintContainer
 
osgi.blueprint.container.symbolicname = org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx.datamodel
 
osgi.blueprint.container.version = 1.0.0.SNAPSHOT
 
service.id = 1092
 
----
 
objectClass = javax.persistence.EntityManagerFactory
 
org.apache.aries.jpa.container.managed = true
 
org.apache.aries.jpa.default.unit.name = false
 
osgi.unit.name = cxfhibernate
 
osgi.unit.provider = org.hibernate.ejb.HibernatePersistence
 
osgi.unit.version = 1.0.0.SNAPSHOT
 
service.id = 1104
 
----
 
objectClass = javax.persistence.EntityManagerFactory, org.apache.aries.jpa.container.sync.Synchronization
 
org.apache.aries.jpa.container.managed = true
 
org.apache.aries.jpa.default.unit.name = false
 
org.apache.aries.jpa.proxy.factory = true
 
osgi.unit.name = cxfhibernate
 
osgi.unit.provider = org.hibernate.ejb.HibernatePersistence
 
osgi.unit.version = 1.0.0.SNAPSHOT
 
service.id = 1105

after restart:

JBossFuse:karaf@root> ls 362
 
 
 
hibernatetx :: Datamodel (362) provides:
 
----------------------------------------
 
objectClass = org.osgi.service.blueprint.container.BlueprintContainer
 
osgi.blueprint.container.symbolicname = org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx.datamodel
 
osgi.blueprint.container.version = 1.0.0.SNAPSHOT
 
service.id = 524

somehow aries-jpa didn't process this bundle...
Guillaume Nodet, Freeman(Yue) Fang, do you know before I start investigating, what may be the cause?

Grzegorz Grzybek I do not think the issue is aries-jpa not processing the bundle, it's the fact that it's not correctly waiting.

During restart, you see aries process the PU of the bundle @ Bundle.RESOLVED state. This fails as it always does.

2015-11-16 12:39:28,954 | INFO  | FelixStartLevel  | Ejb3Configuration                | org.jboss.logging.JDKLogger        64 | 1941 - org.jboss.logging.jboss-logging - 3.1.4.GA | HHH000204: Processing PersistenceUnitInfo [
 
	name: cxfhibernate
 
	...]
 
2015-11-16 12:39:29,040 | INFO  | FelixStartLevel  | ConnectionProviderInitiator      | org.jboss.logging.JDKLogger        64 | 1941 - org.jboss.logging.jboss-logging - 3.1.4.GA | HHH000130: Instantiating explicit connection provider: org.hibernate.ejb.connection.InjectedDataSourceConnectionProvider
 
2015-11-16 12:39:29,061 | WARN  | FelixStartLevel  | container                        | impl.EntityManagerFactoryManager  366 | 1900 - org.apache.aries.jpa.container - 1.0.1.redhat-611452 | Error creating EntityManagerFactory
 
java.lang.IllegalStateException: The bundle org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx.datamodel/1.0.0.SNAPSHOT is not started.
 
	at org.apache.aries.jpa.container.unit.impl.JndiDataSource.getDs(JndiDataSource.java:61)[1900:org.apache.aries.jpa.container:1.0.1.redhat-611452]
 
	at org.apache.aries.jpa.container.unit.impl.DelayedLookupDataSource.getConnection(DelayedLookupDataSource.java:38)[1900:org.apache.aries.jpa.container:1.0.1.redhat-611452]
 
	at org.hibernate.ejb.connection.InjectedDataSourceConnectionProvider.getConnection(InjectedDataSourceConnectionProvider.java:70)[1938:org.hibernate.entitymanager:4.2.9.Final]

But immediately after, the front end bundle resolves and hits an issue around Synchronization and the EMF

2015-11-16 12:39:29,100 | ERROR | FelixStartLevel  | aries                            | a.blueprint.aries.impl.NSHandler  277 | 1898 - org.apache.aries.jpa.blueprint.aries - 1.0.1.redhat-611423 | No org.apache.aries.jpa.container.sync.Synchronization service registered.
 
2015-11-16 12:39:29,121 | INFO  | FelixStartLevel  | BlueprintContainerImpl           | container.BlueprintContainerImpl  348 | 8 - org.apache.aries.blueprint.core - 1.0.1.redhat-611423 | Bundle org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx.cxfhibernate is waiting for dependencies [(&(&(org.apache.aries.jpa.proxy.factory=true)(osgi.unit.name=cxfhibernate))(objectClass=javax.persistence.EntityManagerFactory))]

Immediately after that, the datamodel bundle goes to Bundle.ACTIVE and tries to create the PU again. This time is fails because the datasource bundle is still being created (it did not wait) and the datasource osgi service has not yet been bound.

2015-11-16 12:39:29,124 | INFO  | FelixStartLevel  | Ejb3Configuration                | org.jboss.logging.JDKLogger        64 | 1941 - org.jboss.logging.jboss-logging - 3.1.4.GA | HHH000204: Processing PersistenceUnitInfo [
 
	name: cxfhibernate
 
	...]
 
2015-11-16 12:39:29,144 | INFO  | FelixStartLevel  | ConnectionProviderInitiator      | org.jboss.logging.JDKLogger        64 | 1941 - org.jboss.logging.jboss-logging - 3.1.4.GA | HHH000130: Instantiating explicit connection provider: org.hibernate.ejb.connection.InjectedDataSourceConnectionProvider
 
2015-11-16 12:39:29,162 | ERROR | FelixStartLevel  | container                        | ntainer.unit.impl.JndiDataSource   85 | 1900 - org.apache.aries.jpa.container - 1.0.1.redhat-611452 | The DataSource osgi:service/jdbc/Hibernate_XADS required by bundle org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx.datamodel/1.0.0.SNAPSHOT could not be found.
 
javax.naming.NameNotFoundException: osgi:service/jdbc/Hibernate_XADS
 
	at org.apache.aries.jndi.url.ServiceRegistryContext.lookup(ServiceRegistryContext.java:113)[1896:org.apache.aries.jndi.url:1.0.0]
 
	at org.apache.aries.jndi.url.ServiceRegistryContext.lookup(ServiceRegistryContext.java:144)[1896:org.apache.aries.jndi.url:1.0.0]

You see, the datasource is creating while the other 2 are already active and in GracePeriod.

[1942] [Active     ] [GracePeriod ] [   60] hibernatetx :: CXF Hibernate (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[1943] [Active     ] [GracePeriod ] [   60] hibernatetx :: Datamodel (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[1944] [Active     ] [Creating    ] [   60] hibernatetx :: XA-Datasource (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)

Once the datasource is registered, the datamodel bundle transitions from GracePeriod to Created, but the EMF creation is never attempted again because aries only does it Bundle.RESOLVED and Bundle.ACTIVE state transitions.

[1942] [Active     ] [Failure     ] [   60] hibernatetx :: CXF Hibernate (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[1943] [Active     ] [Created     ] [   60] hibernatetx :: Datamodel (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[1944] [Active     ] [Created     ] [   60] hibernatetx :: XA-Datasource (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)


Fabric8:admin@fuse-services2> osgi:ls 1943
 
 
 
hibernatetx :: Datamodel (1943) provides:
 
-----------------------------------------
 
objectClass = org.osgi.service.blueprint.container.BlueprintContainer
 
osgi.blueprint.container.symbolicname = org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx.datamodel
 
osgi.blueprint.container.version = 1.0.0.SNAPSHOT
 
service.id = 373

If I shutdown again and delete the bundle cache for 1943 (the datamodel) and start, the datamodel is now after the datasource, so it waits in RESOLVED until the datasource bundle is CREATED and from there it works fine as the datasource is registered the EMF create is called at Bundle.ACTIVE on the datamodel.

[root@fusefabric2 cache]# rm -rf bundle1943/
 
 
 
[1942] [Resolved   ] [            ] [   60] hibernatetx :: CXF Hibernate (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[1944] [Active     ] [Creating    ] [   60] hibernatetx :: XA-Datasource (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[1945] [Resolved   ] [            ] [   60] OPS4J Pax Web - Extender - Whiteboard (3.0.6)
 
[1946] [Resolved   ] [            ] [   60] OPS4J Pax Web - Jsp Support (3.0.6)
 
[1947] [Resolved   ] [            ] [   60] Scala Standard Library (2.10.2.v20130530-074427-VFINAL-60d462ef6e)
 
[1948] [Resolved   ] [            ] [   60] wrap_file__root_containers_fuse-services2_fabric8-karaf-1.0.0.redhat-379_data_maven_agent_com_oracle_ojdbc6_12.1.0.1_ojdbc6-12.1.0.1.jar (0)
 
[1949] [Resolved   ] [            ] [   60] wrap_file__root_containers_fuse-services2_fabric8-karaf-1.0.0.redhat-379_data_maven_agent_org_jboss_jandex_1.1.0.Final_jandex-1.1.0.Final.jar (0)
 
[1950] [Resolved   ] [            ] [   60] hibernatetx :: Datamodel (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
Thanks for great analysis . I'll ask Freeman tomorrow morning.

I think the problem comes from the use of JNDI to obtain a reference to the DataSource.
JNDI does not support waiting for the DataSource.

An alternative and better way would be to let aries-jpa manage the DataSource by using the following in the persistence.xml:

-               <jta-data-source>osgi:service/jdbc/Hibernate_XADS</jta-data-source>
 
-               <non-jta-data-source>osgi:service/jdbc/NonXA_DS</non-jta-data-source>
 
+               <jta-data-source>blueprint:comp/dataSource</jta-data-source>
 
+               <non-jta-data-source>blueprint:comp/dataSourceXA</non-jta-data-source>

In the project, the datasource is deployed separately, so there will be a blueprint proxy in between.
Another alternative is to have aries JPA create the datasource:

    <properties>
 
     <!-- These properties are creating the database on the fly. We are using them to avoid the tests having
 
          to create a database  -->
 
      <property name="javax.persistence.jdbc.driver" value="org.apache.derby.jdbc.EmbeddedDriver"/>
 
      <property name="javax.persistence.jdbc.url" value="jdbc:derby:memory:TEST;create=true"/>
 
     <property name="openjpa.jdbc.SynchronizeMappings" value="buildSchema(ForeignKeys=true)"/>
 
     <property name="openjpa.jdbc.DBDictionary" value="derby"/>
 
    </properties>

Guillaume Nodet Grzegorz Grzybek Thanks for the input. I guess the real question is why, in Fabric, do the bundles correctly wait and start in the correct order when you add the profile to the container or if you refresh the profile? The only time they do not correctly wait is when you do stop / start the container when the application is already deployed.

I tested out 'blueprint:comp/dataSourceXA' with my project, but it looks like the blueprint:comp namespace is only valid if the datasource is within the same bundle as the persistence.xml. The datamodel does wait, however it just ends up sitting in Bundle.STARTING for 5 minutes until it times out.

[2747] [Resolved   ] [            ] [   60] hibernatetx :: CXF Hibernate (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[2748] [Starting   ] [            ] [   60] hibernatetx :: Datamodel (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[2749] [Active     ] [Created     ] [   60] hibernatetx :: XA-Datasource (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)


2015-11-25 08:46:55,503 | ERROR | agent-1-thread-1 | container                        | ntainer.unit.impl.JndiDataSource   85 | 2705 - org.apache.aries.jpa.container - 1.0.1.redhat-611452 | The DataSource blueprint:comp/Hibernate_XADS required by bundle org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx.datamodel/1.0.0.SNAPSHOT could not be found.
 
javax.naming.ServiceUnavailableException: The BlueprintContainer service for bundle org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx.datamodel/1.0.0.SNAPSHOT not be located
 
	at org.apache.aries.jndi.url.BlueprintURLContext.getBlueprintContainerRef(BlueprintURLContext.java:450)[2701:org.apache.aries.jndi.url:1.0.0]
 
	at org.apache.aries.jndi.url.BlueprintURLContext.lookup(BlueprintURLContext.java:293)[2701:org.apache.aries.jndi.url:1.0.0]
 
	at org.apache.aries.jndi.url.BlueprintURLContext.lookup(BlueprintURLContext.java:329)[2701:org.apache.aries.jndi.url:1.0.0]
 
	at org.apache.aries.jndi.DelegateContext.lookup(DelegateContext.java:161)[2698:org.apache.aries.jndi.core:1.0.0]
 
	at javax.naming.InitialContext.lookup(InitialContext.java:411)[:1.7.0_60]
 
	at org.apache.aries.jpa.container.unit.impl.JndiDataSource.getDs(JndiDataSource.java:65)[2705:org.apache.aries.jpa.container:1.0.1.redhat-611452]
Did you kept the blueprint xml with the <reference/> elements in the data model bundle ?

Guillaume Nodet I still have this in my datamodel blueprint

	<reference id="dataSource"
 
                interface="javax.sql.DataSource"
 
                filter="(datasource.name=NonXA_DS)" availability="mandatory"/>
 
                
    <reference id="dataSourceXA"
 
                interface="javax.sql.XADataSource"
 
                filter="(datasource.name=Hibernate_XADS)" availability="mandatory"/>
Ok, well, this means that both osgi: and blueprint: suffer from the same problem, they do not wait for the required service to be available and fail fast.

Guillaume Nodet Grzegorz Grzybek Applied the patch, but it doesn't make a difference during restarts. I re-packaged the JAR as a 611453 hotfix 22 to make applying it to fabric easier.

[3040] [Active     ] [            ] [   60] Aries JPA Container (1.0.1.redhat-611453)


[3015] [Active     ] [GracePeriod ] [   60] hibernatetx :: CXF Hibernate (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[3016] [Starting   ] [            ] [   60] hibernatetx :: Datamodel (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[3017] [Resolved   ] [            ] [   60] hibernatetx :: XA-Datasource (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)

During a fresh restart, datamodel always tries to start before the datasource, irrespective is references and import / export services. It ends up like this:

[3082] [Active     ] [GracePeriod ] [   60] hibernatetx :: CXF Hibernate (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[3083] [Active     ] [Failure     ] [   60] hibernatetx :: Datamodel (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)
 
[3084] [Active     ] [Created     ] [   60] hibernatetx :: XA-Datasource (1.0.0.SNAPSHOT)

I added blueprint.timeout:=10000 to speed it up, but this presents the same end result as the osgi:service. 

<Bundle-SymbolicName>org.mrobson.example.hibernatetx.datamodel;blueprint.timeout:=10000</Bundle-SymbolicName>

Doing a container-add-profile works fine. Going a refresh of the profile works fine. Restarting the container with the profile applied always fails because the datamodel always tries to start first due to alphabetical ordering.

Guillaume Nodet I went back and the patch DOES work if you're using osgi:service references from the persistence.xml, it DOES NOT work using the blueprint:comp namespace I was trying this morning (which I think is fine) for now..
Right, that's expected, I only handled the osgi:service/ JNDI urls in the patch.
